description: From Middle English acros, from early Middle English a-croiz, a-creoyz, from Anglo-Norman an (“in, on”) + croiz (“in the form of a cross”); Equivalent to a- +‎ cross. More at cross.

entries.meaning: From one side to the other.
examples: she helped the blind man across;  the river is half a mile across
If we sail off at noon, when will we be across?
He leaned across for a book.

entries.meaning: (crosswords, often in combination) A word that runs horizontally in the completed puzzle grid or its associated clue.
examples: I solved all of the acrosses, but then got stuck on 3 down.

entries.meaning: To, toward, or from the far side of (something that lies between two points of interest).
examples: Fortunately, there was a bridge across the river.
He came across the street to meet me.

entries.meaning: On the opposite side of (something that lies between two points of interest).
examples: That store is across the street.

entries.meaning: (Southern US, African-American Vernacular) across from: on the opposite side, relative to something that lies between, from (a point of interest).
examples: And make sure you're parked across the mall in the outside lot.  […]  Last time I was there, I parked in a parking structure and paid an arm and a leg for it.

entries.meaning: From one side to the other within (a space being traversed).
examples: The meteor streaked across the sky.
Could you slide that across the table to me, please?

entries.meaning: At or near the far end of (a space).

examples: This poetry speaks across the centuries.
All across the country, voters were communicating their representatives.

entries.meaning: So as to intersect or pass through or over at an angle.
examples: Lay the top stick across the bottom one.
She had straps fastened across the conduit every six feet.

entries.meaning: In possession of full, up-to-date information about; abreast of.
examples: As a regular news reader I thought I was across the eccentricities of the US president.
